projects.title: CPT Settlement Calculator
projects.description:
# CPT Analysis & Settlement Calculator

A comprehensive geotechnical engineering web application for analyzing Cone Penetration Test (CPT) data and calculating settlement using Settle3 correlations and methodologies.

![](/images/cpt1.png)
![](/images/cpt2.png)

## ğŸš€ Quick Start

### Option 1: Simple Installation (Recommended)
```bash
# 1. Clone the repository
git clone https://github.com/stevech-AI/cpt-analysis-settlement-calculator.git
cd cpt-analysis-settlement-calculator

# 2. Install dependencies
pip install -r requirements.txt

# 3. Run the application
streamlit run app.py
```

### Option 2: Using pyproject.toml
```bash
# 1. Clone the repository
git clone https://github.com/stevech-AI/cpt-analysis-settlement-calculator.git
cd cpt-analysis-settlement-calculator

# 2. Install dependencies
pip install .

# 3. Run the application
streamlit run app.py
```

**That's it!** The app will automatically open at `http://localhost:8501` in your browser.

ğŸ“– **For detailed installation instructions and troubleshooting, see [INSTALL.md](INSTALL.md)**

---

## ğŸ§ª Testing with Sample Data

The repository includes real CPT test data files in the `test_data/` folder:

```bash
# After running the app, upload any of these files:
test_data/sample_cpt1.txt  # 1 layer, uniform soft soil
test_data/sample_cpt2.txt  # 5 layers, 1,930mm settlement â­ Recommended
test_data/sample_cpt3.txt  # 1 layer, shorter profile
```

**Quick Test:**
1. Start the app: `streamlit run app.py`
2. Go to "ğŸ“¤ Upload CPT Data" tab
3. Upload `test_data/sample_cpt2.txt`
4. Navigate to "Settlement Analysis" tab
5. Click "Calculate Settlement" to see ~1,930mm total settlement results!

See [test_data/README.md](test_data/README.md) for detailed information about each sample file.

## Features

### 1. CPT Data Processing
- **Excel file upload** supporting multiple CPT datasets
- Automatic column detection for depth, qc, fs, and u2
- Normalization calculations (Qt, Fr, Bq, Ic) using Robertson methodology
- Support for various data formats and headers

### 2. Soil Classification
- **Robertson (2009)** soil classification charts
- Automated soil behavior type identification
- Interactive Qt-Fr classification plots with Ic contours
- Soil type distribution analysis

### 3. Automated Soil Layering
- Layer identification based on Ic transitions
- User-adjustable minimum layer thickness
- Automatic merging of thin layers
- Visual layer profiles with depth and thickness

### 4. CPT Correlations
Calculate key settlement parameters from CPT data:
- **Young's Modulus (E)** - for immediate settlement
- **Constrained Modulus (M)**
- **Compression Index (Cc)** - for consolidation settlement
- **Recompression Index (Cr)**
- **Over-Consolidation Ratio (OCR)**
- **Friction Angle (Ï†)** - for sandy soils
- **Undrained Shear Strength (Su)** - for clayey soils
- **Permeability (k)**

### 5. Settlement Analysis
- **Immediate (Elastic) Settlement** calculations
- **Consolidation Settlement** for clay layers
- Total settlement estimation
- Layer-by-layer settlement breakdown
- Support for various loading configurations

### 6. Interactive Visualizations
- CPT profile plots (qc, fs, u2, Qt, Ic)
- Robertson classification charts with data points
- Parameter correlation graphs
- Settlement distribution by layer
- Multi-CPT comparison views

### 7. Export Functionality
- **Excel** exports with complete analysis data
- **PDF** comprehensive reports
- **CSV** layer summaries
- Settlement calculation results

## How to Use

### 1. Upload CPT Data
- Navigate to the "ğŸ“¤ Upload CPT Data" tab
- Upload one or more Excel files containing CPT data
- Files should have columns for: Depth, qc (cone resistance), fs (sleeve friction), and optionally u2 (pore pressure)
- The app will automatically detect column names

### 2. Configure Parameters
Use the sidebar to set:
- **Unit Weight of Soil** (kN/mÂ³)
- **Water Table Depth** (m)
- **Minimum Layer Thickness** (m)
- **Net Area Ratio** for cone

### 3. View CPT Profiles
- Select CPTs to display
- Choose profile type (qc, Rf, u2, Qt, Ic)
- Compare multiple CPTs side-by-side

### 4. Explore Soil Classification
- View Robertson (2009) classification charts
- See soil type distribution
- Analyze Ic contours

### 5. Review Soil Layers
- View automated layer identification
- Export layer data
- Adjust layer thickness parameters if needed

### 6. Analyze Correlations
- Review calculated parameters for each layer
- Compare E, Cc, Cr, OCR across layers
- Export complete analysis to Excel

### 7. Calculate Settlement
- Input loading configuration:
  - Applied load (kN)
  - Footing dimensions (m)
  - Footing depth (m)
- View immediate and consolidation settlement
- Export settlement results and PDF reports

## Test Data Files

Real CPT field data is included in the `test_data/` folder for testing:
- `sample_cpt1.txt` - 1 layer organic clay profile (0mm settlement)
- `sample_cpt2.txt` - 5 layer profile showing significant settlement (1,930mm) â­
- `sample_cpt3.txt` - Single layer profile with shorter depth range (0mm settlement)

All files are tab-delimited format: Depth | qc | fs | u2

See [test_data/README.md](test_data/README.md) for complete details.

## Methodology

### Soil Classification
Based on **Robertson (2009)** normalized CPT methodology:
- Normalized cone resistance: Qt = (qt - Ïƒvo) / Ïƒ'vo
- Normalized friction ratio: Fr = [fs / (qt - Ïƒvo)] Ã— 100%
- Soil behavior type index: Ic = âˆš[(3.47 - log Qt)Â² + (log Fr + 1.22)Â²]

### Correlations
Settlement parameters derived from published correlations:
- **E**: Î±_E Ã— (qt - Ïƒvo), where Î±_E = 0.015 Ã— 10^(0.55Ã—Ic + 1.68)
- **Cc**: Based on plasticity index correlations (Jain et al. 2015)
- **Cr**: GMDH-type neural network (Kordnaeij et al. 2015)
- **OCR**: k Ã— (qt / Ïƒ'vo), where k varies with soil type
- **M**: Î±_M Ã— qt, where Î±_M varies with Qtn

### Settlement Calculations
- **Immediate Settlement**: S = Î£(Î”Ïƒ Ã— H / E) for each layer
- **Consolidation Settlement**: Terzaghi's theory with Cc and Cr
- Accounts for over-consolidation and stress history

## Technical Details

### Built With
- **Streamlit** - Web application framework
- **Pandas** - Data processing
- **NumPy** - Numerical calculations
- **Plotly** - Interactive visualizations
- **SciPy** - Scientific computations
- **FPDF** - PDF report generation

### References
- Robertson, P.K. (2009). "Interpretation of cone penetration tests - a unified approach"
- Settle3 CPT Theory Manual (Rocscience)
- Terzaghi's Consolidation Theory

## Notes

- The app performs calculations based on empirical correlations which have limitations
- Results should be verified by qualified geotechnical engineers
- Engineering judgment is required for final design decisions
- Parameters may need adjustment based on local experience and soil conditions

## Support

For questions about geotechnical engineering principles or settlement calculations, consult relevant technical literature and standards.

projects.title: BlockEngine
projects.description:
# BlockEngine

A geometric modeling library for computing 3D blocks (enclosed regions) formed by analytical plane intersections, designed to improve upon triangle-based approximation methods.

## Introduction

This project serves as a demonstration of using Cursor (AI-assisted development) to tackle a complex geometry and algorithmic problem. The development experience revealed some interesting insights:

**Summary of Results:**
- Kind of very annoying. It seems like it makes good progress on stuff... but then totally falls apart.

## Motivation

### Problems with Existing Approaches (ROC Slope / Tunnel Block Engine)

Current implementations in tools like ROC Slope and Tunnel Block Engine face several significant limitations:

#### 1. **Triangle-Based Approximations**
- Joints (discontinuities) are approximated as triangular meshes/discs
- This approximation leads to:
  - **Poor multi-threading**: Complex mesh operations don't parallelize well
  - **Excessive computation**: Triangle-triangle intersections are computationally expensive
  - **Approximation errors**: Discrete meshing introduces numerical artifacts

#### 2. **Precision Requirements**
- The system requires highly precise values for parameters like "persistence" (thresholds for joint continuity)
- These values are typically:
  - Not well-known or poorly constrained
  - Difficult to measure in practice
  - Sensitive to slight variations

#### 3. **Computational Inefficiency**
- Making even small changes to joint properties requires:
  - **Full recomputation** of all blocks
  - **Complete regeneration** of the entire block structure
  - **No incremental updates** possible

### Our Approach: Analytical Plane-Based Geometry

This project addresses these issues by treating joints as **analytical planes** rather than discrete approximations:

#### **Analytical Plane Representation**
- Joints are represented as infinite analytical planes (normal vector + point)
- Eliminates approximation errors from triangulation
- Provides mathematically exact intersection calculations

#### **Plane Intersection Graph Structure**
- Creates a **tree/graph structure** of plane intersections:
  - Vertices represent intersection points (where 3+ planes meet)
  - Edges represent intersection lines (where 2 planes meet)
  - Faces represent bounded regions on each plane
  - Regions represent fully enclosed volumes (blocks)

#### **Computational Advantages**
1. **More Efficient**: Plane-plane intersection is computationally simpler than triangle-triangle intersection
2. **Better Parallelization**: Graph operations can be more easily parallelized
3. **Incremental Updates**: The graph structure allows for:
   - **Local updates**: Changes to one plane affect only connected regions
   - **Incremental recomputation**: Only affected subgraphs need updating
   - **No full recomputation** required for small changes

#### **Flexible Persistence Functions**
- The graph-based structure enables:
  - **Post-processing application** of persistence functions
  - **Exotic persistence metrics** that can be applied after block computation
  - **Iterative refinement** without recomputing the entire structure
  - **Multiple persistence models** can be evaluated on the same graph

### Architecture Overview

The library is organized into several key components:

- **Plane Grouping**: Groups parallel/near-parallel planes for efficiency
- **Intersection Computation**: Calculates plane-plane and three-plane intersections
- **Graph Construction**: Builds face adjacency graphs representing topological relationships
- **Enclosed Region Detection**: Identifies fully enclosed volumes (blocks) from the graph structure

## Project Structure

```
BlockEngine.Core/          - Core geometric algorithms and data structures
BlockEngine.Visualization/ - 3D visualization using OpenTK
BlockEngine.Demo/          - Demo application with multiple test scenarios
BlockEngine.Core.Tests/    - Unit tests for core functionality
```

## Getting Started

### Prerequisites

- .NET 8.0 SDK
- Visual Studio 2022 or VS Code (recommended)

### Building

```bash
dotnet build BlockEngine.sln
```

### Running the Demo

```bash
dotnet run --project BlockEngine.Demo/BlockEngine.Demo.csproj
```

### Running Tests

```bash
dotnet test BlockEngine.Core.Tests/BlockEngine.Core.Tests.csproj
```

## Demo Controls

- **Left mouse + drag**: Rotate camera
- **Mouse wheel**: Zoom in/out
- **Number keys (0-9)**: Switch between scenarios
- **PageUp/+**: Increase plane size
- **PageDown/-**: Decrease plane size
- **T**: Toggle between original and processed (grouped) planes
- **R**: Toggle showing enclosed regions (computed from face adjacency graph)
- **ESC**: Close window

![alt text](/images/Planes.png)

![alt text](/images/Block.png)

## Future Work

- Performance optimization. There are many, many steps here that are very, very poorly implemented.
- the demo I think is still not rendering some blocks? I think?
- Incremental graph update algorithms
- Advanced persistence function implementations
